<s> Can you provide guidance on a streaming service that excels in original content, with a focus on quality shows and movies across various genres?I'm trying to create a short list of services to show off on a website and I think I've got a good base, but I'd really like to find a service that stands out and I'd like to get some help with this as the services I've been looking at are all quite similar. I've tried to focus on the services I would personally consider, if I had to choose, and have taken note of their available content on various sites.I've looked at HBO Max, Disney+, Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Apple TV+, Crave, Shudder, Britbox and a few others, but I'm open to other recommendations if you have anything that really stands out. I would really like the service to have a wide range of original content, or at least a wide range of different kinds of content.What I have found is that the content is quite similar on the available services and my personal favourites at the moment are Shudder and Disney+. I've found it hard to come to an overall decision, though, and I don't want to pick just one of those two as they're both great, but the question remains whether there's another service that stands out that I may not have considered.Can anyone provide some guidance?posted by kittypurry to Media & Arts (12 answers total) 12 users marked this as a favoriteYouTube Premium.It's not like Netflix. They don't even bother to release new shows and movies in the US. It's entirely focused on the most amazing, fun, weird and diverse content that has no interest in appealing to the mainstream.I think it's actually the best value right now (especially if you don't want ads). You get an ad free youtube plus free access to the new and improved YouTube Music (and the regular old YouTube with ads if you really can't live without them).posted by 20yearlurkerson at 6:26 PM on June 26, 2021 [1 favorite]The new Star Trek shows are on Paramount+, which also has lots of Paramount movies in addition to original content and Paramount Network (formerly Spike, which has shows from Comedy Central, MTV, etc.).posted by Mavri at 6:29 PM on June 26, 2021 [1 favorite]Disney+ is all about the Disney stuff, right?posted by Cash4Lead at 6:30 PM on June 26, 2021You can check out this handy guide to the top 10 streaming services in Australia. It doesn't have a huge amount of original content but the originals they do have are quite good. I personally have a subscription to both Disney+ and Amazon Prime and they are great but I have a very wide range of taste.The best thing about all of these streaming services (well, the one's I have experience with at least) is that they're not mutually exclusive. If you want to watch everything from a given service, you can subscribe to both.Having said that, I would still recommend HBO Max to your readers. While it might not have an incredible amount of variety (I think they are really focusing on the Max branding for their high quality content) it has the best original shows by far. <s> Could you recommend a streaming service that stands out for its family-friendly content, with a variety of options suitable for viewers of all ages?My streaming service of choice is Netflix. The streaming service offers a wide variety of entertainment, including movies, television shows, documentaries and educational shows. Netflix also produces its own original content that is suitable for a wide range of viewers.Here are some features of Netflix that make it a great streaming service for families:Large Selection of Family-Friendly Content: Netflix has a large selection of family-friendly content, including movies, TV shows, documentaries, and educational shows. There are also family-oriented original shows and films available on Netflix, like "Big Mouth," "The Kissing Booth," and "The Worst Witch."Parental Controls: Netflix offers parental controls that allow parents to set restrictions on the content their children can watch. Parents can block mature content, set ratings for each member of the family, and set time limits on streaming.Kid-Friendly Profile: Netflix offers a separate kid-friendly profile that allows children to access age-appropriate content. The kid-friendly profile includes shows and movies that are specifically designed for children, such as "Dinotrux," "Dragons: Race to the Edge," and "Trolls: The Beat Goes On."Streaming Abroad: Netflix has a large library of content available to stream, even outside of the United States. If you travel abroad or live abroad, you can access Netflix's library of shows and movies in most countries.Overall, Netflix is a great streaming service for families, with a large selection of family-friendly content, parental controls, a kid-friendly profile, and the ability to stream content abroad. It's a great option for families who want to watch shows and movies together without having to worry about the content being inappropriate.Netflix is a streaming service that offers a variety of movies and TV shows. It also offers original content, documentaries, and educational shows.The service is available on a variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets, smart TVs, game consoles, and streaming players.Netflix also offers a feature called "Kids Profiles," which allows parents to control what their children can watch on the service.To sign up for Netflix, you can visit their website or download their app from the App Store or Google Play.There is no official Netflix price for kids profiles.To set up a Kids Profile on Netflix, you need to log into your account, go to "Your Profile" and click on the "Create a Kids Profile" option. Then you need to enter the age of the child you want to add, and choose the content they can access.</s>

If your friend becomes defensive or hostile, it’s best to walk away from the conversation and focus on having a positive interaction with him at a later time.Ultimately, the best approach will depend on your relationship with your friend and the specific circumstances of the situation. The amount of time it takes to get over a loss will vary from person to person, and there is no timeline that everyone must follow.It’s normal to feel a range of emotions after a loss, including sadness, anger, and guilt. These feelings can be intense at first, but they will likely lessen over time as you begin to adjust to your new reality.One of the most important things you can do during this time is to be kind to yourself and allow yourself to feel the pain of your loss. Don’t try to suppress your emotions or push them away. Instead, allow yourself to feel them and express them in healthy ways, such as through journaling or speaking with a therapist.You may also find it helpful to connect with other people who are grieving. Sharing your experience with others can provide support and help you feel less alone.Finally, be patient with yourself as you go through the grieving process. There is no right or wrong way to grieve, and you may not be able to move on from your loss right away. <s> I'm in the market for a streaming service that prioritizes high-quality audio and video streaming. Are there any platforms known for delivering top-notch streaming quality and resolution?I'm mostly interested in services that prioritize quality streaming over cost.This is a highly subjective question. But a place to start is YouTube TV or Netflix, but not the cheapest. YouTube TV, at $55/month, is expensive compared to cable or satellite. However, they use Google's servers for the streaming and have their own video encoder to deliver a good picture quality. Netflix has their own encoder too and they have a 4K plan for $18/month. Both are great quality. YouTube TV has a bunch of channels, but it is more geared toward entertainment. Netflix is more for watching movies and TV.What is your internet connection speed and what type of devices are you using to access this service?I have a 50-50 split between mobile/web and TV. My internet is about 150/15 and I live in a relatively rural area (so not the best connections are available). I would prefer to avoid Netflix due to the "Netflix tax" on the device. So, I don't care to have 4K and don't mind 1080p. I want a service that has good streaming quality. I will occasionally need to stream over WiFi, but mostly over cellular connections.I've heard of using the "download to device" feature and I'll probably use that for some titles, but I don't mind downloading stuff over a wired connection.I was just looking at Hulu today and they're offering a limited amount of channels that they're able to use because they use the cable/satellite connections to provide the channel feeds to the service. But, they have a really cheap plan that has no ads and only a limited amount of streaming quality. But, it's a good choice for streaming over WiFi since they don't have ads. They also have a Live TV option which provides the same channel feeds as cable/satellite providers, but you pay for a plan which includes those channels.You don't mention a price you're willing to pay.I can get YouTube TV for $55/month. And, that is all I need (for now) and has a good library of movies.I'm just a little frustrated with Netflix's "Netflix Tax". It's $13/month for 4K. Which is ridiculous.I'd love to hear about other streaming services that are good and inexpensive.</s>

<s> I'm a fan of immersive and original series. Can you recommend a streaming service that consistently produces compelling and critically acclaimed original series across various genres?A) You need to choose between Netflix and Amazon Prime. Neither is a cheap date, but both offer quality, diverse, and engaging content across a wide range of genres.B) But first you need to do the hard yards and sign up for a free trial with both services, so you can experience and compare for yourself.I'm going to suggest Netflix. Netflix is more of a binge-on-TV-shows service than a binge-on-movies service, and I'm one of those people who wants to feel like I'm binge-watching when I'm watching TV. For me, that means I want to watch multiple episodes in a row, and it also means I'm interested in watching more than one show at a time. So, binge-on-movies service HBO and I aren't a great fit, even though they're the best at what they do.The great thing about Netflix is they offer a range of TV shows across multiple genres, from a range of countries. You can binge on Stranger Things, Black Mirror, Master of None, and Orange Is the New Black; get the whole family together to watch Stranger Things and Master of None; get the whole family together to watch Star Wars: The Clone Wars; have a serious debate about the value of socialism and the validity of racial stereotypes with Orange Is the New Black; watch a range of documentaries; and stream movies as long as you're not trying to watch multiple movies at once. I watch Netflix a lot, because they have a range of shows I can watch at the same time, and I can stream in HD and even UHD.I'm not saying you'll be as keen on all of the shows on Netflix, but if you take a chance on one or two, I think you'll enjoy your binge-watching experience.As for shows you might not have heard of, try Altered Carbon, Love, Dear White People, Atypical, Bloodline, Narcos, The Get Down, House of Cards, and Arrested Development.And, finally, as for genres: Comedy, Drama, Thriller, Crime, Horror, Documentary, Romance, Sci-Fi, Kids, and Animated.But be warned, because of their wide range, Netflix is expensive.</s>

<s> I'm a fan of immersive and original series. Can you recommend a streaming service that consistently produces compelling and critically acclaimed original series across various genres?-Karen M., St. Paul, MinnesotaYou want binge-worthy, critically acclaimed series across different genres? You’re not alone.In 2020, Netflix streamed a whopping 400 million hours of its original series worldwide each week. HBO Max, its closest competitor, came in with 140 million hours each week.While Netflix’s “Stranger Things” and “Bridgerton” and HBO Max’s “Love Life” and “Legally Blonde” have racked up accolades and attention in recent months, there are more streaming services vying for your attention.From Apple to Roku and Quibi to Disney+, streaming services are creating a glut of content. And some of it is pretty good. So, let’s get started.Apple TV+ has an impressive slate of originals, including the Oscar-nominated “The Elephant Whisperers” and “CODA” and the hit “Ted Lasso.” But it’s also home to shows such as “Ted Lasso,” which received 20 Emmy nominations, and “Servant,” starring Toby Kebbell and Rupert Grint.The latter is a spooky show about a family that comes to life after a supernatural experience with a nanny. It’s not for the squeamish and features disturbing violence. It’s worth watching, but it’s not for everyone.Because Apple TV+ is available as part of Apple’s $15-a-month subscription package, it’s probably not the best place for the newcomer looking to sample different streaming services.In addition to Ted Lasso, Apple TV+ offers originals such as the thriller "Severance" and the drama "WeCrashed." And if you're looking for more of a family-friendly lineup, Apple TV+ has "Central Park" and "The Shrink Next Door," starring Will Ferrell.Disney+ is one of the best streaming services around, and its original series are often among the best. Some of the most popular shows on Disney+ include “WandaVision,” “Loki,” and “The Falcon and the Winter Soldier.”While these shows are geared toward adults, they do have a fair amount of kid-friendly content as well. Some of the best kids’ shows on Disney+ include “Star Wars: The Bad Batch” and “Zootopia+.” There’s also a wide variety of classic and current movies available, including many of the most popular Marvel films.For $7.99 a month, or $79.99 a year, you can stream on up to four devices at once. If you’re a sports fan, Disney+ offers a ton of college football games and other live events. It’s also the only streaming service that offers the Disney Vault, where you can find classic Disney films, such as “The Lion King” and “Pinocchio.”Peacock is the free streaming service of NBCUniversal, which also owns Telemundo and Bravo. Peacock is home to “The Office” and “Parks and Recreation,” as well as its own original shows, such as “Yellowstone” and “The Girl Before.”Peacock also has live TV and sports, and there are no ads. There are two plans available, one for $4.99 a month and another for $9.99 a month, with ads. There’s a free version, but it’s not ad-free and has some restrictions.Peacock’s library includes more than 35,000 movies and TV shows, including some that were exclusive to other streaming services. The service has a unique feature called “Binge Pass,” which gives you access to the entire library for $5 a month.If you’re looking for an all-in-one streaming service, Paramount+ is a great choice. It also won for Best Television Movie or Mini-series and Best Documentary Series. There are a number of great series to watch, including The Crown, House of Cards, Making a Murderer, Narcos and Orange is the New Black.The original series available on Amazon Prime is not quite as rich, but there are still a few standouts. If you are a fan of the original series 24, then The Man in the High Castle should be at the top of your list. If you prefer a dark drama with strong characters, then Transparent is the series for you. The Kids in the Hall, the classic Canadian sketch comedy show, has been revived on Amazon. If you are a fan of the original series Mad Men, you may enjoy the show's reboot, Sneaky Pete.You can also watch the critically acclaimed series produced by AMC, HBO, Showtime and CBS All Access. The top shows to check out are Breaking Bad, which won the Emmy for Best Drama Series; Silicon Valley, which won for Outstanding Comedy Series; Homeland, which won for Best Drama Series; Big Little Lies, which won for Best Limited Series; and The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel, which won for Best Comedy Series.</s>
